p: The dental pulp is largely vascularized and therefore infectious agents present in the blood can easily reach the dental tissue both in humans and other animals [ 17, 20, 21, 38]. The tissue has been used as a common source for the recovery of nucleic acid from past and ancient infections such as Yersinia pestis from the teeth of skeletons dating from the XVI and XVII centuries [ 17]. The entry of infectious agents into the tooth and, particularly, the dental pulp, seems to trigger the activation of several pathogen recognition receptors (PRR) in response to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMP), as an important tissue devoted to the innate immune system [ 39].
